div.p: The aim of this publication is to maintain and develop a tradition of international collaboration - between archaeologists and epigraphers from many countries, and their colleagues in Libya - in publishing the inscriptions of Libya. The inscribed texts presented here have been published by a range of expert scholars. They have been assembled and curated by Charlotte Roueché, and their publication in this format has been enabled by her colleagues, Gabriel Bodard (London) and Irene Vagionakis (Bologna). The aim is to make to provide a richly documented corpus of these materials in a format which is easily accessible, easily searched, and freely available.

In 1946 the archaeologist John Ward-Perkins, who had served with the British Army in Libya during the second World War, was appointed Director of the British School at Rome (BSR), while Richard Goodchild (VIAF), another British archaeologist, was appointed Director of Antiquities under the British Administration of Libya. In the same year Joyce Reynolds, a classics graduate working on Roman history came to Rome on a scholarship. Over the next few years the three worked together to collect and study the Roman inscriptions of Tripolitania; based in Rome, Reynolds was able to collaborate extensively with Italian archaeologists who had studied and published many of these texts. The resultant work, Inscriptions of Roman Tripolitania (IRT), was published in 1952, and was a model of collaborative work.

A major weakness of the 1952 publication was the limited amount of illustration that was possible, from the very large collection of photographs held at the BSR. The production of an online second edition of IRT, with full illustration, was first suggested to the British School by Michael Greenhalgh (Australian National University), who produced a prototype version. A subsequent version was developed on the basis of his work by a BSR team assembled by Andrew Wallace-Hadrill, the Director; this included Raphael Helman, Sophy Downes, Raphael Cormack, and Jo Wallace-Hadrill, who together prepared the whole text in electronic form. The best form for publication was however not yet clear. In the 2000s Reynolds, and her pupil Charlotte Roueché, who had been working together on the inscriptions of Aphrodisias, also started to explore online publication, using EpiDoc markup. A challenge which had been of concern to Reynolds for many years was the difficulty of providing accurate geodata for a country where such information was restricted on security grounds. The emergence in the 2000s of publicly available tools based on satellite imagery, such as Google Earth, transformed this, among many archaeological projects. To test the possibilities, therefore, Reynolds, Roueché and Bodard agreed with the BSR to use IRT as a test case, working with Dr Tom Elliott of Pleiades, and with the Epigraphische Datenbank Heidelberg, in the Concordia project. The team transformed the text into EpiDoc; they made no editorial changes to the content, but Reynolds provided new English translations for all the texts. The resultant resource was published in 2009, Inscriptions of Roman Tripolitania (2009), and received with enthusiasm, particularly in Libya, where it was presented in Tripoli in May 2010.

The 2009 publication included no items beyond those published by Reynolds in 1952 or added in 1955. Since 1955 many scholars have worked on the inscriptions of Tripolitania, both improving the published texts and publishing new ones. This work has been faithfully recorded in L'Année Épigraphique; the Epigraphische Datenbank Heidelberg made the texts available in EpiDoc XML, which has simplified the process of adding the new texts to the present collection. In every case we have presented the most recently published version of the text.

div.head: HGL
div.p: Dr Hafed Walda undertook the mapping for the Concordia project, and provided co-ordinates for all the locations, which could then be mapped onto Google Earth. In the process he built a database; he went on to add equivalent data for the texts in the sister project, Inscriptions of Roman Cyrenaica. It became increasingly clear that this was producing a resource which was useful in its own right, and could record other significant locations, providing Unique Identifiers and multiple toponyms. Roueché, aided by Valeria Vitale, added information from Geonames, Pleiades, and from specialist sources, such as the Archeological Guides by Philip Kenrick. Neil Jakeman (ORCID), of King's Digital Laboratory, created an interface which allowed the publication, in 2016, of the Heritage Gazetteer of Libya, under the aegis of the Society for Libyan Studies; data continue to be added by volunteers.

div.head: EFES
div.p: The appearance at the end of 2017 of the open source EFES publication platform has opened new possibilities for the open and sustainable publication of a digital epigraphic corpus such as IRT. EFES is based on the Kiln platform developed for publication of TEI XML projects at the Department of Digital Humanities and King’s Digital Lab, which is used for several EpiDoc corpora; the game-changing features of EFES are its focus on EpiDoc XML and inclusion of epigraphic indices by default, and its adoption by the EpiDoc development community.

The EpiDoc Front-End Services tool (EFES) was designed to fill the important need for a publication solution for researchers and editors who have produced EpiDoc-encoded texts but do not necessarily have access to digital humanities support or a well-funded IT service to produce a bespoke Web publication for them. The EFES development team, led by Bodard, comprised Polina Yordanova (customisation, testing, training and documentation) and Jamie Norrish (software development), and the tool was further tested and developed by several collaborators from other projects, including Martina Filosa (ORCID), Tamara Kalkhitashvili, Alessio Sopracasa (ORCID), Simona Stoyanova and Irene Vagionakis. EFES can be deployed with a minimum of technical skill, and may also be customised with a wide variety of display, index and search features, either from the EpiDoc toolkit, or custom built for the individual project.

EFES therefore provided the basis for the IRCyr2021 digital publication, which means that it is compatible and consistent with other EpiDoc publications, and especially future instalments of the Inscriptions of Libya corpus. The use of standard indices, search facets, and authority lists of terms such as monument types, symbols and lists of people and places will enhance cross-corpus interoperability, and enable integration with large multinational projects such as the EAGLE Network and Epigraphy.info. Planned future developments in EFES, including built-in geographic visualisation, date and time search, and Linked Open Data export functionality, will easily be adopted into the platform, and offer new features to Inscriptions of Libya projects. It is our intention to develop increasing interoperability and cross-searchability between all the projects.

div.head: IRT2021
div.p: In 2018 a grant from the Society for Libyan Studies enabled Simona Stoyanova to set up an EFES edition of the Inscriptions of Roman Cyrenaica. A further grant from the Society, in 2021, has allowed us to start work on preparing IRT 2021, an enhanced and enriched version of IRT 2009, in a more stable digital structure. The corpus will be made accessible initially to a limited group of colleagues with direct experience of working with the inscriptions of Tripolitania; they will be invited to contribute in any way they might wish, whether with emendations, illustrations, or even new items. We very much hope that this can provide an example of a new level of collaborative work in epigraphy, using the digital environment to build on the principles of the original publication.
